review.title: Topic segmentation via community detection in complex networks
review.abstract: Many real systems have been modelled in terms of network concepts, and written texts are a particular example of information networks. In recent years, the use of network methods to analyze language has allowed the discovery of several interesting findings, including the proposition of novel models to explain the emergence of fundamental universal patterns. While syntactical networks, one of the most prevalent networked models of written texts, display both scale-free and small-world properties, such representation fails in capturing other textual features, such as the organization in topics or subjects. In this context, we propose a novel network representation whose main purpose is to capture the semantical relationships of words in a simple way. To do so, we link all words co-occurring in the same semantic context, which is defined in a threefold way. We show that the proposed representations favours the emergence of communities of semantically related words, and this feature may be used to identify relevant topics. The proposed methodology to detect topics was applied to segment selected Wikipedia articles. We have found that, in general, our methods outperform traditional bag-of-words representations, which suggests that a high-level textual representation may be useful to study semantical features of texts.

sections.heading: II. COMPLEX NETWORK APPROACH
sections.text: The approach proposed here for segmenting texts by topic is based on a networked representation of texts. In this section we also describe the method for identifying network communities, as the proposed method requires prior segmentation of text networks.

sections.heading: Representing texts as networks
sections.text: This is only possible if the application of this model in clustering analysis is not widespread, but traditional word-adjacent networks are not organized into communities when considering large pieces of text. In this paper we advocate that there is a strong relationship between communities and subjects. Therefore, we modify the traditional word-adjacent model to get an improved representation of word interactions in written texts. Specifically, we present here a triple extension that does not adjacent words.Prior to the creation of the model itself, some pre-processing is applied.

sections.heading: III. DATABASE
sections.text: The artificial dataset we created to evaluate the methods consists of paragraphs extracted from Wikipedia articles. Selected articles can be divided into 8 different topics and 5 different subtopics: 1. Actors: Jack Nicholson, Johnny Depp, Robert De Niro, Robert Downey Jr. and Tom Hanks.2. sections.heading: IV. RESULTS
sections.text: In this section, we analyze the statistical characteristics of the proposed models in terms of their organization in communities. We also evaluate the performance of our model in the artificial data set and compare it with simpler models that are not based on networked information.

sections.heading: Modularity analysis
sections.text: For this reason, we are investigating how the modularity of networks depends on the model parameters. < The unique parameter that can influence the modularity of networks in our models is ω, which amounts to the removal of links in texts (see definition in the description of the EC model in Section II). Note that the distance ω controls the total number of edges of the network, so comparing the network modularity for different values of ω is equivalent to comparing networks with different averages. Since the average degree plays an important role in calculating modularity [26], we have defined a normalized modularity QN here that only takes into account the organization of the network in modules and is not distorted in the direction of dense networks.

sections.heading: Performance analysis
sections.text: In order to evaluate the performance of the proposed network-based methods, we have developed two additional methods based on linguistic attributes to compare the performance of networked and non-networked methods in Section III. However, both methods are based on a pocket-of-words strategy [1], in which each paragraph is represented by the frequency of occurrence of its words. To cluster the paragraphs in different subjects, we have used two traditional clustering methods: k-means [46] and expectation maximization [47], in which the pocket-of-words strategy is represented, based on the k-means and expectation maximization algorithms are referred to as BOWK and BOW-EM-EM, maximizing the results of maximization [47].
